verses.text: "Comfort, comfort my people," says your God.
verses.comment: God speaks words of comfort after declarations of judgment. The repetition emphasizes His compassion and mercy. This parallels God's father-like comfort throughout Scripture (see 2 Cor. 1:3-4).

verses.text: Speak tenderly to Jerusalem, and proclaim to her that her warfare has ended, that her guilt is pardoned, for she has received from the LORD's hand double for all her sins.
verses.comment: God promises restoration to Jerusalem. The phrase 'her guilt is pardoned' hints at God's ability to forgive sin. The concept of penance and satisfaction for sin is reflected here.

verses.text: A voice cries out: "In the wilderness prepare the way of the LORD; make straight in the desert a highway for our God."
verses.comment: This prophecy is fulfilled in John the Baptist preparing the way for Christ (cf. Matt. 3:3). The way is 'prepared' through repentance and conversion, echoing both moral and sacramental preparation.

verses.text: Every valley shall be raised up, and every mountain and hill made low; the rough ground shall become level, and the rugged places a plain.
verses.comment: Symbolically, God is removing obstacles for His people. Spiritually, it points to God’s power to transform hearts, and the universality of salvation (see Luke 3:5).

verses.text: Then the glory of the LORD will be revealed, and all flesh will see it together, for the mouth of the LORD has spoken."
verses.comment: The ultimate revelation of God's glory occurs in the Incarnation of Christ (John 1:14). The phrase 'all flesh' anticipates universal access to salvation.

verses.text: A voice says, "Cry out." And I said, "What shall I cry?" "All flesh is grass, and all its beauty is like the flower of the field.
verses.comment: Human life is fleeting, in contrast to God's enduring word. This is quoted in 1 Peter 1:24, showing its enduring theological importance.

verses.text: The grass withers, the flower fades when the breath of the LORD blows upon it; surely, the people are grass.
verses.comment: The fleeting nature of human life underlines the need for reliance on God. This prepares hearts for dependence on God’s enduring revelation.

verses.text: The grass withers, the flower fades, but the word of our God will stand forever.
verses.comment: Unlike human glory, God’s word is unchanging and eternal. Jesus affirms this (Matt. 24:35), highlighting the security found in revealed truth.

verses.text: Go up to a high mountain, O Zion, bearer of good news; lift your voice with strength, O Jerusalem, bearer of good news; lift it up, do not be afraid; say to the cities of Judah, "Behold your God!"
verses.comment: "Good news" here anticipates the announcement of the Gospel. Zion (God’s chosen city) is the messenger — a symbol of the people bringing the message of salvation.

verses.text: Behold, the Lord God comes with might, and His arm rules for Him; see, His reward is with Him, and His recompense accompanies Him.
verses.comment: God comes as the righteous judge—with reward and recompense. This looks forward to Christ’s return (Rev. 22:12), affirming the unity of judgment and mercy.

verses.text: He will tend His flock like a shepherd; He will gather the lambs in His arms and carry them close to His heart; He will gently lead the mothers with their young.
verses.comment: This verse prefigures Jesus, the Good Shepherd. God’s personal, gentle care is a recurring theme leading to New Testament fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: Who has measured the waters in the hollow of His hand, or marked off the heavens with a span, enclosed the dust of the earth in a measure, and weighed the mountains in scales and the hills in a balance?
verses.comment: This poetic language highlights God’s incomprehensible power as Creator—He alone sets the limits of creation and sustains all things.

verses.text: Who has directed the Spirit of the LORD, or as His counselor has taught Him?
verses.comment: No one can advise God. Paul cites this to declare God’s wisdom (Rom. 11:34); all revelation is from Him.

verses.text: With whom did He consult, and who taught Him, and showed Him the path of justice, or taught Him knowledge, or showed Him the way of understanding?
verses.comment: God’s wisdom is ultimate; He needs no teacher. This is a vital doctrine regarding Divine omniscience and infallible truth.

verses.text: Look, the nations are like a drop from a bucket, and are counted as dust on the scales; behold, He takes up the islands as fine dust.
verses.comment: This emphasizes the insignificance of earthly power compared to God. God’s sovereignty surpasses all nations and rulers.

verses.text: Lebanon is not sufficient for fuel, nor are its animals enough for a burnt offering.
verses.comment: God is so great that no earthly sacrifice is adequate for Him. This anticipates the need for the perfect and sufficient sacrifice.

verses.text: All the nations are as nothing before Him; they are counted by Him as less than nothing and emptiness.
verses.comment: Again underlining divine supremacy, this verse counters pride in human achievement apart from dependence on God.

verses.text: To whom then will you liken God, or what likeness will you compare with Him?
verses.comment: God’s uniqueness sets Him apart from all idols; He cannot be represented by images (cf. the Second Commandment).

verses.text: An idol! A craftsman casts it, and a goldsmith overlays it with gold and casts for it silver chains.
verses.comment: The folly of idolatry is exposed: gods made by human effort cannot save. True worship looks beyond material substitutes to divine reality.

verses.text: He who is too poor for such an offering chooses wood that will not rot; he seeks a skilled craftsman to set up an idol that will not move.
verses.comment: Idolatry, regardless of one’s means, is futile. This highlights the importance of authentic, not superficial, worship.

verses.text: Do you not know? Do you not hear? Has it not been told you from the beginning? Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?
verses.comment: Creation itself testifies to God’s power and revelation, a theme reflected in Romans 1:20.

verses.text: It is He who sits above the circle of the earth, and its inhabitants are like grasshoppers; who stretches out the heavens like a curtain, and spreads them out like a tent to dwell in;
verses.comment: God’s transcendence and sovereignty are emphasized. Humanity is small before His creative authority.

verses.text: who brings princes to nothing and makes the rulers of the earth as emptiness.
verses.comment: Earthly rulers have no ultimate power against God’s will. This is a recurring warning to trust in God, not human authority.

verses.text: Hardly are they planted, hardly sown, hardly has their stem taken root in the earth, when He blows upon them, and they wither, and the whirlwind carries them away like stubble.
verses.comment: Leaders and empires rise and fall by God’s sovereignty. No temporal power lasts, only God's kingdom endures.

verses.text: "To whom then will you compare Me, that I should be like him?" says the Holy One.
verses.comment: Through rhetorical question, God affirms His absolute uniqueness and holiness, reinforcing proper worship and reverence.

verses.text: Lift up your eyes on high and see: who created these? He who brings out their host by number, calling them all by name; by the greatness of His might, and because He is strong in power, not one is missing.
verses.comment: God’s intimate care for creation is shown: He knows each star. This degree of authority undergirds faith in Him.

verses.text: Why do you say, O Jacob, and speak, O Israel, "My way is hidden from the LORD, and my right is disregarded by my God"?
verses.comment: God’s people doubt His care in hardship, but there is assurance in His providence. This challenges faith to trust in God's providence even when unseen.

verses.text: Have you not known? Have you not heard? The LORD is the everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth. He does not grow faint or weary; His understanding is unsearchable.
verses.comment: God is immutable and all-powerful—contrasting human frailty. The doctrine of God’s eternity and omnipotence grounds trust in Him.

verses.text: He gives power to the faint, and to him who has no might He increases strength.
verses.comment: God’s grace provides spiritual strength for the weary. This reflects sanctifying grace given to the faithful.

verses.text: Even youths shall faint and be weary, and young men shall fall exhausted;
verses.comment: Human strength always fails eventually. Spiritual and supernatural help is needed, underscoring the necessity of divine grace.

verses.text: but those who wait for the LORD shall renew their strength; they shall mount up with wings like eagles; they shall run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint.
verses.comment: Faithful endurance is rewarded. Waiting on God—persevering in faith and hope—leads to renewal and supernatural strength. Patience and faithful perseverance are essential virtues for the believer.
